revision.text:
{{Infobox sport | name = Equestrian vaulting | image = Voltige123.jpg | alt = | imagesize = | caption = Freestyle team vaulting | union = [[International Federation for Equestrian Sports]] (FEI) | nickname =Vaulting | first = | firstlabel = | region = | registered = | clubs = | contact = no | team = individual and teams of varying numbers | mgender = yes | type = indoor or outdoor | equipment = [[horse]], [[surcingle]], [[longeing]] equipment | venue = Generally indoor arena with dirt or similar footing suitable for the horse | olympic = 1920 Antwerp only | paralympic = }} [[File:Vaulting at Kentucky Horse Park.webm|thumb|Vaulting at Kentucky Horse Park]]
'''Equestrian vaulting''', or simply '''vaulting''',<ref name=volt>{{cite web|title=The Voltiging Federation of Ontario|url=http://www.horses-of-the-sun.ca/VFO.htm|publisher=Horses of the Sun, Canada|accessdate=June 2011}}</ref> is most often described as [[gymnastics]] and [[dance]] on horseback, which can be practiced both competitively or non-competitively.<ref>[http://equestrianvaulting.com.au/ Equestrian Vaulting Australia | Home<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Vaulting has a history as an equestrian act at [[circus]]es,<ref name=lox>{{cite book|last=Loxton|first=Howard|title=The golden age of the circus|year=1997|publisher=Smithmark|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0-7651-9909-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-p5llSm6W7wC|page=38}}</ref><ref name=brit>{{cite book|title=The New Encyclopædia Britannica|year=2003|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica Inc.|location=Chicago, Ill.|isbn=978-0-85229-961-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d5kxAQAAIAAJ|edition=[New ed.].|page=419, volume 16}}</ref> but its origins stretch back at least two-thousand years. It is open to both men and women and is one of ten equestrian disciplines recognized by the [[International Federation for Equestrian Sports]] (Fédération Équestre Internationale or '''FEI''').<ref name=fei>{{cite web|title=About us – standards|url=http://www.horsesport.org/about-us/standards|publisher=Fédération Équestre Internationale|accessdate=August 2011}}</ref> Therapeutic or interactive vaulting is also used as an activity for children and adults who may have balance, attention, gross motor skill or social deficits.
Vaulting's enthusiasts are concentrated in Europe and other parts of the [[Western world]]. It is well established in Germany and Switzerland and is growing in other western countries. Vaulting was first introduced in the United States in the 1950s and 60s but was limited only to California and other areas of the west coast.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.americanvaulting.org/startclub/aboutus/history.php Alumni Only - American Vaulting Association<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> More recently, it is beginning to gain popularity in the United States northeast.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/26/travel/escapes/26horsevault.html?_r=1&pagewanted=1</ref>
==History== It is believed by some that the origins of vaulting could be traced to the ancient Roman games, where acrobats usually displayed their skills on cantering horses. Others, however, believe that vaulting originated in [[ancient Crete]], where [[bull-leaping]] was prevalent. In either case, people have been performing acrobatic and dance-like movements on (or over) the backs of moving horses/animals for more than 2,000 years.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
Renaissance and Middle Ages history include numerous references to vaulting or similar activities. The present name of the sport/art comes from the French "la voltige," which it acquired during the Renaissance, when it was a form of riding drill and agility exercise for cavalry riders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vaulting.org.uk/index.php?page=history-of-vaulting|title=A Brief History of Vaulting|publisher=British Equestrian Vaulting|accessdate=August 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716092319/http://www.vaulting.org.uk/index.php?page=history-of-vaulting|archive-date=16 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Modern vaulting developed in post-war Germany as an initiative to introduce children to equestrian sports.
In 1983, vaulting became one of the disciplines recognized by the FEI. European championships were first held in [[Ebreichsdorf]], Austria in 1984, and the first FEI World Vaulting Championship was held in [[Bulle]], Switzerland in 1986. Vaulting was included in the [[World Equestrian Games]] in [[Stockholm]] in [[1990 FEI World Equestrian Games|1990]] and in all subsequent editions of the games. It was demonstrated as an art during the 1984 and 1996 Olympic Games events. It has been included in the Inter-Africa Cup since 2006.<ref name=iac>{{cite web|title=Inter-Africa Cup|url=http://vaulting4africa.piczo.com/inter-africacup?cr=5&linkvar=000044|accessdate=August 2011}}</ref>
The first World Cup Vaulting competition was held in [[Leipzig]] on 29–30 April 2011.<ref name=fei2>{{cite web|title= LOOSER AND WIEGELE TAKE INAUGURAL FEI WORLD CUP™ VAULTING TITLES|url=http://www.horsesport.org/media/press-releases/looser-and-wiegele-take-inaugural-fei-world-cup%E2%84%A2-vaulting-titles|publisher=Fédération Équestre Internationale |date=30 April 2011| accessdate= August 2011}}</ref>
==Competitive vaulting== [[File:Individual vaulting.jpg|thumb|left|Individual freestyle]] In competitive vaulting, vaulters compete as individuals, pairs (pas-de-deux) and teams. Beginning vaulters compete in walk or [[trot]] while experienced vaulters compete in [[canter]]. The vaulting [[horse]] moves in a minimum 15-metre diameter circle and is directed by a lunger (or "longeur") who stands in the center. In competitive vaulting, the rider and horse will both be judged on a scale from 1 to 10.
Vaulting competitions consist of compulsory exercises and choreographed freestyle exercises done to music. There are seven compulsory exercises: mount, basic seat, flag, mill, scissors, stand and flank. Each exercise is scored on a scale from 0 to 10. Horses also receive a score and are judged on the quality of their movement as well as their behavior.
Vaulters compete in team, pas-de-deux and individual categories. An individual freestyle (also known as Kür) is a 1-minute program, the pas-de-deux kür is 2 minutes while the team is 4 minutes. They are all choreographed to music. The components of a freestyle vaulting routine ''may'' include mounts and dismounts, handstands, kneeling and standing and aerial moves such jumps, leaps and tumbling skills. However, many of these skills are only seen in the highest levels. A typical routine for a child or beginner will more likely contain variations on simple kneels and planks. Teams also carry, lift, or even toss another vaulter in the air. Judging is based on technique, performance, form, difficulty, balance, security, and consideration of the horse; the horse is also scored, taking up 25% of the total score.
Vaulting horses are not saddled but wear a surcingle (or a roller) and a thick back pad. The surcingle has special handles which aid the vaulter in performing certain moves as well as leather loops called "cossack stirrups". The horse wears a bridle and side reins. The lunge line is usually attached to the inside bit ring.
Vaulting horses typically move on the left rein (counterclockwise), but in some competitions the horse canters in the other direction. Two-phase classes of competition also work the horse to the right. While many European clubs do not compete to the right, they still work at home evenly both directions, believing this benefits the horse and the vaulter.
The premier vaulting competitions are the biannual World and Continental Championships and the World Equestrian Games (WEG) held every four years. In many countries, vaulting associations organize and sponsor national, regional and local events every year. In 2011 there were at least 24 countries with such organisations.<ref name=ivclinks>{{cite web|title=Links|url=http://www.vaultingclub.com/Links.html|publisher=International Vaulting Club|accessdate=August 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720134218/http://www.vaultingclub.com/Links.html|archive-date=20 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Competition movements== Vaulters perform movements on the back of the horse. Novice and beginning vaulters may perform at the walk or the trot while higher level vaulters perform at the canter. There are compulsory exercises and depending on class the vaulter performs seven or eight of them:<ref name=rules>{{cite web|title=FEI Vaulting Rules 8th Edition, Chapter VI, Article 739|url=http://www.fei.org/disciplines/vaulting/rules|work=FEI Homepage|accessdate=27 December 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Vlag Equestrian vaulting.jpg|thumb|left|Compulsory Flag]]
{| class="wikitable" |- !Movement !Description |- |Vault On |The vault-on leads to the frontways seat on the horse. After jumping on both feet, the right leg swings up immediately, as high as possible, lifting the pelvis higher than the head, while the left leg remains stretched down. The shoulders and hips are parallel to the shoulder axis of the horse. When the pelvis is at the highest possible point, the vaulter lowers the stretched right leg and lands softly, erect and centred in the seat astride with the upper body vertical. |- |Basic Seat |An astride position (the vaulter sits on the horse as a rider would), with the arms held to the side and the hands raised to ear level. Hands should be held with closed fingers and palms facing downward, with the fingers arching slightly upward. Legs are wrapped around the horse's barrel, soles facing rearward, with toes down and feet arched. Vaulter holds this position for four full strides. |- |Flag |From the astride position, the vaulter hops to his or her knees and extends the right leg straight out behind, holding it slightly above his or her head so the leg is parallel to the horse's spine. The other leg should have pressure distributed through the shin and foot, most weight should be on the back of the ankle, to avoid digging the knee into the horse's back. The left arm is then stretched straight forward, at a height nearly that of the right leg. The hand should be held as it is in basic seat (palm down, fingers together). The right foot should be arched and the sole should face skyward. This movement should be held for four full strides after the arm and leg are raised. |- |Mill |From the astride position, the vaulter brings the right leg over the horse's neck. The grips must be ungrasped and retaken as the leg is brought over. The left leg is then brought in a full arc over the croup, again with a change of grips, before the right leg follows it, and the left leg moves over the neck to complete the full turn of the vaulter. The vaulter performs each leg movement in four strides each, completing the Mill movement in sixteen full strides. During the leg passes, the legs should be held perfectly straight, with the toes pointed. When the legs are on the same side of the horse, they should be pressed together. |- |Scissors 1st part |From the astride position, the vaulter swings into a handstand. At the apex, the vaulter's body should be turned to the lunger and the inner leg should be crossed over the outer leg. The vaulter than comes down and lands so that she is facing backward on the horse, toward the tail. |- |Scissors 2nd part |From seat rearways on the horse the vaulter swings up with the outside leg over the inside leg, and lands facing forward once again. If the vaulter lands hard on the horse's back, they are severely penalized. Scissors is judged on the elevation of the movement. |- |Stand |The vaulter moves from the astride position onto the shins and immediately onto both feet, and releases the grips. The vaulter then straightens up with both knees bent, the buttocks tucked forward, and the hands held as they are in basic seat. The vaulter must hold the position for four full strides. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060512133954/http://www.englishvaultingsquad.co.uk/photos/saumur05-a22.jpg] |- |Flank 1st part |From the astride position, the legs are swung forward to create momentum, before swinging backward, and rolling onto the stomach with a straight body, with a full extension of the legs so that the vaulter nearly reaches a handstand. At the apex, the vaulter jackknifes her body and turns the body to the inside, before sliding down into a side seat. The vaulter is judged on form, landing, and elevation. |- |Swing off |From seat astride, the vaulter swings to handstand position with closed legs, arms extended to attain maximum elevation. At maximum arm extension, the vaulter pushes against the grips, and as a result of shoulder repulsion, attains additional elevation and maximum flight, landing to the inside of the horse, facing forward, on both feet. |}
[[File:Freestyle team Habighorst.jpg|thumb|right|Team Freestyle]]
The compulsories are performed in succession in the above order, without pause or dismounts.
==Dress code== The International Federation for Equestrian Sports (FEI) regulates dress codes for competitive vaulting. Every 2–3 years, new guidelines are released, which consistently declare that vaulters must wear form-fitting uniforms that do not conceal the line and form of the vaulter's body, as well as not hinder the movement of the vaulter or the safe interaction between the vaulters.<ref>http://www.fei.org/sites/default/files/file/DISCIPLINES/VAULTING/Rules/Vaulting%20Rules%20-Final%2014.10.2011%20-%20GA.pdf {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120801073557/http://www.fei.org/sites/default/files/file/DISCIPLINES/VAULTING/Rules/Vaulting%20Rules%20-Final%2014.10.2011%20-%20GA.pdf |date=1 August 2012 }}, article 713</ref> For that reason, accessories such as belts, capes or hats are prohibited. Additionally, men’s trousers must be secured at the ankle. It is expected that clothing be appropriate for the competition and does not give the effect of nudity. The most common form-fitting uniforms worn by vaulters are [[unitard]]s.<ref name=rules2>{{cite web|title=FEI Vaulting Rules 8th Edition, Chapter II, Article 713|url=http://www.fei.org/disciplines/vaulting/rules|work=FEI Homepage|accessdate=27 December 2012}}</ref>
==Non-competitive vaulting== In addition to competition, vaulting is a form of artistry, recreation and entertainment. Vaulters range in age from 7 to 30 years and older, practicing individual and team skills and routines. The youngest athletes begin at the walk gait and progress to trot, and canter, based on strength, height, and ability to mount and performing on the horse.
Vaulting is used on a therapeutic level in some instances. People with disabilities can often benefit from interacting with the horse and team members, and by doing simple movements with the help of "spotters."
Vaulting is often seen on a recreational level, through vaulting "demonstrations," and occasionally in local parades.
==See also== * [[Horse riding stunts]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== <!-- Sub-Sort Alphabetical Order? -->

===National links=== *[http://www.americanvaulting.org/ American Vaulting Association (USA)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130724000524/http://www.yaninavaulting.com.ar/ Argentine Equestrian Vaulting] *[http://www.equestrianvaulting.com.au/ Equestrian Vaulting Australia] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120922163845/http://www.volti-info.at/ Voltigier-Ausschusses (Austria)] *[http://www.britishvaulting.org/ British Equestrian Vaulting] *[http://www.vaultcanada.org/ VaultCanada.org] *[http://www.vaultingcolombia.com Vaulting Colombia] *[http://www.ceskavoltiz.cz/ Česká voltiž (Czech Republic)] *[http://www.asvef.com Association Sportive de Voltige Equestre Française (France)] *[http://www.vaulting-for-malawi.com/ Vaulting for Malawi] *[http://www.voltige.nl/ Den Helder (Netherlands)] *[http://www.voltige.no/ Voltige Ni wa nA (Norway)] *[http://www.voltiz.sk Slovakian Vaulting Federation] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111005102627/http://www.horsesport.org.za/vaulting/index.htm South Africa] *[http://www.voltige.ch/ Swiss Vaulting Federation] *[http://www.rideforbund.dk/da/Ridesport/Discipliner/Voltigering.aspx Dansk Rideforbund Voltigering (Denmark)]

revision.text:
{{see also|List of FA Cup Finals}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = FA Cup Final | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_caption = | image = England mai 2007 040.jpg | caption = The new [[Wembley Stadium]] on 19 May 2007, the day it held its first FA Cup Final | status = Active | genre = Sporting event | date = May | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annual | venue = | location = [[London]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | coordinates = | country = | years_active = | first = {{Start date|1872|df=y}} | founder_name = | last = | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = | area = | budget = | activity = | patron = | organised = [[The Football Association]] | filing = | people = | member = | sponsor = | website = | footnotes = }} {{EngvarB|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}}
The '''FA Cup Final''', commonly referred to in England as just the '''Cup Final''', is the last match in the [[FA Cup|Football Association Challenge Cup]]. It is one of the [[List of sports attendance figures|most attended domestic football event]]s in the world, with an official attendance of 89,472 at the 2017 final. The match is the culmination of a knockout competition among clubs belonging to [[The Football Association]] in England, although Scottish and Irish teams competed in the early years and Welsh teams regularly compete, with [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] winning the Cup in [[1927 FA Cup Final|1927]] and reaching the final in [[1925 FA Cup Final|1925]] and [[2008 FA Cup Final|2008]].
{{as of|2018}}, 137 FA Cup Finals have been played. The [[2018 FA Cup Final|latest final]] was held on 19 May 2018 at [[Wembley Stadium]] and was contested between [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], with Chelsea winning 1–0.
==History== The [[1872 FA Cup Final|first FA Cup Final]] was held at [[The Oval|Kennington Oval]] on 16 March 1872 and was contested between [[Wanderers F.C.|Wanderers]] and [[Royal Engineers A.F.C.|Royal Engineers]], with Wanderers winning 1–0.
After the [[1873 FA Cup Final|1873 final]] was held at [[Lillie Bridge Grounds|Lillie Bridge]], the event was held at the Oval until 1892. The [[1893 FA Cup Final|1893]] and [[1894 FA Cup Final|1894]] finals were respectively held at [[Fallowfield Stadium]] in Manchester and [[Goodison Park]] in Liverpool, before the event returned to London in 1895, being held at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre#Crystal Palace FA Cup Finals 1895.E2.80.931914|Crystal Palace]] until the outbreak of [[World War I]]. After the war, the event was held at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], before [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] opened in 1923. The [[1923 FA Cup Final|first final at Wembley]], in which [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] beat [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] 2–0, had an official attendance of 126,047, although the actual figure is believed to be as much as 300,000.
Wembley continued to host the final until 2000, when it closed for redevelopment. The [[Millennium Stadium]] in [[Cardiff]] hosted the final between 2001 and 2006, before the new [[Wembley Stadium]] opened in 2007.
Up to and including 1998, if the final ended in a draw, a replay would be required. This occurred on 14 occasions, the last being in [[1993 FA Cup Final|1993]] between Arsenal and [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]. In September 1998, the Football Association decided that all future finals would be decided 'on the day', meaning that a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] would decide the winner if the score was level after normal and [[Overtime (sports)|extra time]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Maume |first=Chris |date=24 September 1998 |title=Football: End of Cup Final replay |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-end-of-cup-final-replay-1200475.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=26 August 2017}}</ref> Two finals since have been decided by a penalty shootout, those of [[2005 FA Cup Final|2005]] (Arsenal defeating [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]) and [[2006 FA Cup Final|2006]] ([[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] defeating West Ham United).
[[Stan Mortensen]]'s [[association football#hat trick|hat-trick]] for [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in [[1953 FA Cup Final|1953]] remains the only hat trick ever scored at Wembley in the competition's final.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/low/football/fa_cup/990464.stm "The Matthews Final" – BBC Sport]</ref> [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]'s [[Louis Saha]] scored a goal after 27.9 seconds in the [[2009 FA Cup Final]]. It is currently the fastest goal in FA Cup Final history. Bury's 6–0 victory over Derby County in the [[1903 FA Cup Final]] is the largest winning margin. With his goal in the [[2012 FA Cup Final|2012 Final]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea's]] [[Didier Drogba]] became the first man to score a goal in four different Finals.
The FA Cup Final is one of ten events reserved for live broadcast on UK terrestrial television under the [[Ofcom Code on Sports and Other Listed and Designated Events]].
==Winners== ''For a full list of FA Cup winners and runners-up, see [[List of FA Cup Finals]].''
==See also== {{portal|English football}} *[[FA Cup Final referees]] *[[FA Cup semi-finals]] *"[[Abide with Me]]"

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Australian paintings]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]] in sub cat
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file=Sidney Nolan Footballer.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=230px | title=Footballer | artist=[[Sidney Nolan]] | year=[[1946 in art|1946]] | type=enamel paint on composition board | height_metric=121.9 | width_metric=91.4 | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Melbourne]] | museum=[[National Gallery of Victoria]] }} '''''Footballer''''' is a [[1946 in art|1946]] painting by [[Australia]]n artist [[Sidney Nolan]]. It depicts an [[Australian rules football]]er standing before a crowd of spectators at a football match. For many years the painting was thought to be a generic image of a footballer, however Nolan later revealed that the painting is based on [[Bill Mohr]], a star player for the [[St Kilda Football Club]] during the 1930s.
In 2002, the painting was acquired by the [[National Gallery of Victoria]], and has become one of the gallery's most popular works.<ref>[https://twitter.com/ngv_melbourne/statuses/193829075616415744 "Tweet by @ngv_melbourne"] (21 April 2012). ''[[Twitter]]''. "Sidney Nolan was born in Carlton on this day in 1917. His 'Footballer' is one of the most loved works in our Collection". Retrieved on 3 July 2012.</ref><ref name="perkin">Perkin, Corrie (15 March 2008). [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/creative-codes/story-e6frg8n6-1111115769189 "Creative codes"], ''The Australian''. Retrieved 24 June 2012.</ref> According to journalist [[Geoff McClure]], ''Footballer'' "has special significance because, together with [[Russell Drysdale|Drysdale]]'s ''[[The Cricketers]]'', it represents virtually the entire sports-related work ever done by our masters."<ref name="mcclure">McClure, Geoff (29 July 2002). [http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/07/28/1027818484844.html "Operation Full-Back"], ''The Age''. Retrieved 11 August 2012.</ref>
==Background== [[File:Bill Mohr.jpg|thumb|left|''Footballer'' is based on St Kilda's Bill Mohr.]] Born in the inner-[[Melbourne]] working class suburb of [[Carlton, Victoria|Carlton]] on 22 April 1917, Nolan grew up in bayside [[St Kilda, Victoria|St Kilda]], Melbourne's main leisure precinct. His childhood was spent playing in and around [[Luna Park, Melbourne|Luna Park]], [[St Kilda Pier]] and along nearby beaches, jetties and sea baths; memories of this period played an inspirational role in the imagery of Nolan's early paintings, including the ''Bathers'' series which he started in 1942. Nolan also had many sporting interests growing up, in particular swimming, cycling, [[cricket]] and [[Australian rules football]]. He regularly went on weekend trips to the outer at the [[St Kilda Cricket Ground]] to barrack for his team, the [[St Kilda Football Club]].<ref name="nolan"/>
In the mid-1940s, when Nolan was painting boyhood recollections of St Kilda and "heroic" figures such as [[bushranger]] [[Ned Kelly]], he decided to paint ''Footballer'', an "emblematic portrait of the sports-warrior".<ref name="jellie">Jellie, Dugald (29 March 2012). [http://m.smh.com.au/opinion/politics/to-live-football-is-to-truly-belong-20120328-1vym1.html "To live football is to truly belong"], ''The Sydney Morning Herald''. Retrieved 11 August 2012.</ref> The work was painted in the dining room at [[Heide Museum of Modern Art#Early history|Heide]], the [[Templestowe, Victoria|Templestowe]] home of art patrons [[John Reed (art patron)|John]] and [[Sunday Reed]], on 24 August 1946. In his journal, Nolan writes: "Finished my painting of a footballer this morning and called Jim [the gardener at Heide] to have a look at it. He said it looked quite real, almost as if you were there, so it at least passed the critical eye of a specialist."<ref name="jellie"/> Its completion date falls in the middle of Nolan's iconic first series of 27 Ned Kelly works, all but one painted in the Heide dining room. Together with the Kelly series, ''Footballer'' has been interpreted as a "veiled self-portrait"—both men, like the artist, stand outside society in a "space no longer governed by everyday rules."<ref name="mcaullife">McAullife, Chris (26 July 2008). [http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts/the-games-people-display/2008/07/24/1216492633142.html "The games people display"], ''The Age''. Retrieved 11 August 2012.</ref><ref name="jewel">[http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/artworks/jewel-sidney-nolan/3144636 Jewel: Sidney Nolan], [[ABC Radio National]]. Retrieved 11 August 2012.</ref>
The painting was first exhibited at the Melbourne branch of the Contemporary Art Society in 1946, and later shown in retrospective exhibitions throughout the 1960s and 70s with the title ''Fullback, St Kilda'', which led to speculation that the footballer is based on Test cricketer and St Kilda fullback [[Keith Miller|Keith "Nugget" Miller]], of whom Nolan was a great fan. Nolan later revealed in an interview that St Kilda's [[Bill Mohr]] is the subject,<ref name="jewel"/> saying "I lived in St Kilda and I went to a lot of matches there and they had a fullback called Billy Mohr and in 1946, after coming out of the army and casting back for memories to paint, I decided to paint him."<ref name="nolan">Pearce, Barry. ''Sidney Nolan''. Sydney: [[Art Gallery of New South Wales]], 2007. {{ISBN|1-74174-013-4}}, pp. 71–72</ref>
==Composition== The footballer's red, white, yellow and black colours reference those adopted by the Saints during [[World War I]].<ref>Longmire, Anne. ''The Show Goes On: The History of St Kilda, Volume III, 1930 to 1983''. Melbourne: Hudson Publishing, 1983. {{ISBN|0-949873-26-8}}, p. 147</ref> His black shorts "share a singularity and intensity akin to Ned Kelly's helmet", while the broad-striped guernsey—bold against the amorphous backdrop of spectators' faces and vertical lines of the goalpost and boundary fence—prefigures the horizontal bars of escaped [[Convicts in Australia|convict]] David Bracefell in Nolan's [[Eliza Fraser]] series.
==National Gallery of Victoria purchase== The painting, valued in 2002 at approximately $500,000, was on the National Gallery of Victoria's wish list for many years. The gallery acquired the painting in 2002 from a private collector based in England, with costs met jointly by the [[Government of Victoria (Australia)|State Government of Victoria]] and [[Foster's Group]].<ref name="debut">O'Connor, Angela; Roberts, Jo (6 September 2002). [http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/09/05/1031115911903.html "A sporting Nolan to make its debut"], ''The Age''. Retrieved 14 August 2012.</ref> It was officially gifted to the gallery by [[Premier of Victoria|Premier]] [[Steve Bracks]] on [[Nine Network|Channel Nine]]'s ''[[The Footy Show (AFL)|The Footy Show]]'', becoming the first painting to go on display at the newly built [[Ian Potter Centre]], home of the National Gallery of Victoria's Australian art collection.<ref name="debut"/>
==Legacy== ''Footballer'' is used as the cover image for Volume II of [[David Williamson]]'s 1986 publication ''Collected Plays'', which contains his 1977 football play ''[[The Club (play)|The Club]]''.<ref>Williamson, David. ''Collected Plays Volume II''. Sydney: [[Currency Press]], 1986. {{ISBN|0-8681-9287-2}}, p. 256</ref>
In 2011, the National Gallery of Victoria celebrated its 150th anniversary with a range of festivities including life-size renditions of the gallery's most loved works populated along [[St Kilda Road]] to the Ian Potter Centre. At [[Federation Square]], high-flying circus performers played [[kick-to-kick]] as a tribute to ''Footballer'', where a shearing display was also held in commemoration of [[Tom Roberts]]' 1890 painting ''[[Shearing the Rams]]''.<ref>Plant, Simon (28 May 2011). [http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/ngv-brings-art-to-life-for-birthday/story-fn6bn9st-1226064289742 "NGV brings art to life for birthday"], ''Herald Sun''. Retrieved 14 August 2012.</ref>
[[Australia Post]] issued a stamp in 2017 featuring Nolan's ''Footballer''.<ref>[https://australiapostcollectables.com.au/articles/celebrating-two-iconic-australian-artists?ecid=LK20170314001 "Celebrating two iconic Australian artists"] (14 March 2017), Australia Post. Retrieved 15 March 2017.</ref>
==See also== *[[Australian rules football in Australian popular culture]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.ngv.vic.gov.au/col/work/70461 ''Footballer'']—National Gallery of Victoria collection

{{Infobox golf tournament | name = Greater Vancouver Open | image = | location = [[Surrey, British Columbia]], [[Canada]] | establishment = [[1996 PGA Tour|1996]] | course = {{nowrap|Northview Golf & Country Club,}} Ridge Course | par = 71 | yardage = {{convert|7072|yd}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sk1WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nOsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1244%2C469343 |work=Eugene Register-Guard |location=(Oregon) |title=Golf: PGA Tour at Surrey, British Columbia |date=September 2, 2002 |page=6E}} | tour = [[PGA Tour]] | format = [[Stroke play]] | purse = [[United States dollar|$]]3.5 million | month_played = August / September | aggregate = | to-par = | current_champion = | final_year = [[2002 PGA Tour|2002]] | final_champion = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Gene Sauers]] }} {{Location map |Canada |relief = 1 |label = Surrey |lat = 49.125 |long = -122.765 |caption = Location in [[Canada]] |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 235 }} {{Location map |Canada British Columbia |relief = 1 |label = Surrey |lat = 49.125 |long = -122.765 |caption = Location in [[British Columbia]] |marksize = 5 |position = |float = |background = |width = 180 }} The '''Greater Vancouver Open''' was a professional [[golf]] tournament in [[Canada]] on the [[PGA Tour]], held in [[Greater Vancouver|southwestern]] [[British Columbia]] from [[1996 PGA Tour|1996]] to [[2002 PGA Tour|2002]]. It was played after the [[Men's major golf championships|majors]] in late summer, at the Northview Golf & Country Club in [[Surrey, British Columbia|Surrey]], a suburb southeast of [[Vancouver]]. For its first three years, it was an alternate event in late August, concurrent with the [[NEC World Series of Golf]] at [[Firestone Country Club|Firestone]] in [[Akron, Ohio]]. In [[1999 PGA Tour|1999]], the new [[Barracuda Championship|Reno-Tahoe Open]] became the alternate event for the [[1999 WGC-NEC Invitational|WGC-NEC Invitational]] at Firestone. The Vancouver tournament was promoted to a regular tour event and scheduled a week later, as the [[Greater Milwaukee Open]] moved up to July. Renamed the "[[Air Canada]] Championship," sponsored by the country's leading airline, it was coupled with the [[Canadian Open (golf)|Canadian Open]] for consecutive tournaments north of the [[United States|U.S.]] border in early September. [[Mike Weir]] won that year for the first of his eight tour wins; he became the first Canadian to win a PGA Tour event on home soil in {{nowrap|45 years.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kGNWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IPIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3842%2C5083976|work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=wire services |title=Oh Canada! Weir wins |date=September 6, 1999 |page=C2}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HGBIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9QMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6558%2C2510519|work=Toledo Blade |location=(Ohio) |agency=wire services |title=Eagle lifts Weir to Air Canada title |date=September 6, 1999 |page=32}}}} Three weeks earlier, he co-led the [[1999 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] after three rounds,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sFdIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wx4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3160%2C6663983 |work=Sunday Star-News |location=(Wilmington, North Carolina) |agency=Associated Press |title=Woods, Weir an odd couple in final round |date=August 15, 1999 |page=1C}} but finished in a tie for tenth. Weir later won a major at the [[Masters Tournament|Masters]] in [[2003 Masters Tournament|2003]]. The purses grew substantially during the run of the event, from [[United States dollar|$]]1 million to $3.5 million in six years. It was replaced on the schedule in [[2003 PGA Tour|2003]] by the [[Dell Technologies Championship|Deutsche Bank Championship]] in [[Massachusetts]], near [[Boston]]. This was not the first time the PGA Tour included a stop in British Columbia on their schedule. [[Dow Finsterwald]] won the unofficial 1955 '''British Columbia Open Invitational''', and [[Jim Ferree]] was victorious at the 1958 '''Vancouver Open Invitational'''.{{cite web|title=Air Canada Championships 2001-Event Preview|url=http://www.golftoday.co.uk/tours/2001/aircanada/preview.html}} ==Winners== {|class=wikitable style="font-size:95%" !Year!!Winner!!Country!!Score!!To par!!Margin
of victory!!Runner(s)-up||Purse

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name= Estadio Isidoro García (official name) | image =[[File:Seats in cholo.JPG|center|215px]] | location = Avenida Colby William Duscombe, [[Mayagüez, Puerto Rico|Mayagüez]], [[Puerto Rico]] | broke_ground = January 11, 2008 | opened= February 8, 2010{{Citation| last1 = del Valle | first1 = Sara| title = Cuba anunciará mañana si viene| newspaper = El Nuevo Dia| date = February 9, 2010| url = http://www.elnuevodia.com/cubaanunciaramananasiviene-669713.html| accessdate = February 9, 2010}} | surface = | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]48.7 million | architect = | tenants= [[Indios de Mayagüez]]
[[2010 Central American and Caribbean Games]]
[[2011 Caribbean Series]] | seating_capacity= 10,500 }} '''Estadio Isidoro García''' is a baseball stadium in [[Mayagüez]], named after '''Isidoro "El Cholo" García''', a local pitcher who threw the first ever no-hitter at a final series game in the [[Puerto Rico Baseball League]]. The stadium is located south of the city, at road PR-63, also named the ''Avenida Colby William Dunscombe'' (named after a former medical director of the local [[Seventh-day Adventist Church|Adventist]] Bella Vista Hospital). The site lies north of the [[Mayaguez Athletics Stadium]] (finished in December 2009) and across the street from the [[Parque del Litoral]]. ==Old stadium== The original "Cholo García" stadium was a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Mayagüez, Puerto Rico|Mayagüez]], [[Puerto Rico]], originally built in 1938. The stadium was [[demolition|demolished]] after the 2006-2007 [[Puerto Rican Professional Baseball League|Puerto Rico Professional Baseball League tournament]], and was rebuilt as one of the main facilities where the [[2010 Central American and Caribbean Games]], held in the city in the late summer of 2010, were staged. The [[Indios de Mayagüez]] are now using the new stadium as their ballpark. The original stadium was named after García, the first Puerto Rican baseball pitcher to ever throw a [[No-hitter|no-hit no-run]] game in a final series game in the PRBL. The new facility retains the name. A statue of García resides in front of the stadium's main entrance. ==New stadium== The new Isidoro García Baseball Stadium is a 10,500-seat capacity [[stadium]] in [[Mayagüez, Puerto Rico|Mayagüez]], [[Puerto Rico]]. It hosts the home games of [[Indios de Mayagüez]] of the [[Puerto Rico Baseball League]]. It hosted the [[Baseball at the 2010 Central American and Caribbean Games]]. It replaces the former Isidoro García Baseball Stadium, which closed in 2007, but it is located in the same grounds as the original. The [[2011 Caribbean Series]] was held at the stadium [http://www.periodicolaestrella.com/deportes.asp?ID=1426 Confirmada la sede del 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929133845/http://www.periodicolaestrella.com/deportes.asp?ID=1426 |date=2011-09-29 }} It will house the regional offices of the Sports and Recreation Department of Mayagüez.http://www.afi.gobierno.pr/proy_estadio_mayaguez_isidorogarcia.htm Then-governor of Puerto Rico [[Luis Fortuño]] announced completion of the stadium on February 8, 2010, at a press conference held on the stadium's infield. The stadium was built following [[MLB|Major League Baseball]] standards. ==Gallery== File:Front of cholo garcia.JPG|Front of Stadium File:Isodorogarcia.JPG|Stadium under construction. File:Presidentes.JPG|Mission Chiefs of ODACABE Nations in front of the new Isidoro Garcia Stadium File:Night_view_of_Isidoro_Garcia_Baseball_Stadium.jpg|Night view of the Stadium ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico}} * [[Indios de Mayagüez]] * [[2010 Central American and Caribbean Games]] * [[2011 Caribbean Series]] ==External links== *[http://www.slideshare.net/BAQUERO2008/boletin-afi-mayaguez-2010-febrero-2009 Stadium information] *[http://mayaguez2010.blogspot.com/ Designs of stadium] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|18|11|34.58|N|67|09|17.96|W|region:US-PR|display=title}} {{2010 Central American and Caribbean Games venues|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Isidoro Garcia Baseball Stadium}} [[Category:Sports in Mayagüez, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Mayagüez, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:2010 Central American and Caribbean Games venues]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue |name=MSG Sphere London |nickname= |native_name= |native_name_lang= |fullname= |former names= |logo_image= |logo_caption= |image= |image_alt= |caption= |address= [[London]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom]] |location= [[Stratford, London|Stratford]] |coordinates= |type= |genre= |broke_ground=TBD |built= |opened=TBD |renovated= |expanded= |closed= |demolished= |owner=[[The Madison Square Garden Company]] |operator=[[The Madison Square Garden Company]] |surface= |scoreboard= |production= |cost= |architect= Populous |project_manager= |structural engineer= |services engineer= |general_contractor= |main_contractors= |seating_type= |capacity=18,000 |suites= |record_attendance= |dimensions= |field_shape= |acreage= |volume= |tenants= |embedded= |website= [https://london.msg.com/ Official Website] |publictransit= {{rint|london|underground}} {{rint|london|dlr}} {{rint|london|overground}} {{rint|london|crossrail}} {{rint|london|rail}} [[Stratford station]]
{{rint|london|dlr}} {{rint|london|rail}} [[Stratford International station]]
{{rint|london|bus}} [[Stratford City bus station]]
{{rint|london|bus}} [[Stratford bus station]] }} The '''MSG Sphere London''' is a proposed music and entertainment venue to be built in [[Stratford, London|Stratford area]] of [[London]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2018/02/14/populous-build-spherical-music-venue-las-vegas-usa-london-uk-msg-sphere-london|title=Populous to build spherical music venues in Vegas and London|date=2018-02-14|work=Dezeen|access-date=2018-10-10|language=en-US}} ==History== The MSG Sphere London was proposed by [[The Madison Square Garden Company]] and will be identical to the [[MSG Sphere Las Vegas|MSG Sphere Las Vegas.]] Both will be designed by the architects [[Populous (company)|Populous]]. The venue will be located in [[Stratford, London|Stratford]] near the [[Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park]] and [[Westfield Stratford City]]. Once complete, the sphere-shaped venue will have [[LED]] screens inside and outside of the venue and will have a seating capacity of 18,000. {{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/all-you-need-to-know-about-the-planned-msg-sphere-london-a3897671.html|title=All you need to know about the planned MSG Sphere London|website=London Evening Standard|accessdate=2018-10-20}} The MSG Sphere will be built on a site that was used as a coach park during the [[2012 Summer Olympics]]. The Madison Square Garden Company claims that with a population close to 8.8 million, the London metropolitan area only has two large capacity venues for concerts. The MSG Sphere intends to help meet the demands of the London market.[https://www.msglondonconsultation.com/ourproposals/ Our proposals for MSG Sphere London] According to the official website for the MSG Sphere, public comments will be reviewed by the end of 2018. [https://www.msglondonconsultation.com PUBLIC CONSULTATION FOR MSG SPHERE LONDON] ==Features== The MSG Sphere will be equipped with 19,000 by 13,500 resolution LED screens which will spread across the interior of the venue. All 18,000 seats will have high speed internet access. The sound system will deliver sound through the floorboards. The exterior of the venue will feature a 360 degree IMAX display which will allow those who are outside of the venue to see what is going on inside. [http://www.thembj.org/2018/11/the-msg-sphere-the-future-of-live-concert-experiences/ The MSG Sphere: The Future of Live Concert Experiences] ==Transport links== The MSG Sphere will be accessible through a variety of mass transit links, including rail and bus. ===Rail=== The MSG Sphere London will be accessible via the [[London Underground]]'s [[Central line (London Underground)|Central line]] and [[Jubilee line]] at the [[Stratford station]]. Spectators will also be able to access the MSG Sphere via [[Docklands Light Railway]] at Stratford station and [[Stratford International station]]. The [[North London line]] of the [[London Overground]] also stops at Stratford station. [[National Rail]] and [[Crossrail]] customers will be able to access the venue via Statford station. ===Bus=== Spectators will be able to access the venue via bus through the [[Stratford City bus station]] and the [[Stratford bus station]]. ==See also== *[[Ericsson Globe]] ==External Links== *[https://london.msg.com/ Official Website] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Madison Square Garden Company}} {{coord|51.545935|-0.009248|region:GB_scale:5000_type:city_source:Wikimapia|display=title}} [[Category:Madison Square Garden Company]] [[Category:Music venues in London]] [[Category:Sports venues in London]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in London]] [[Category:Boxing venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Proposed sports venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Stratford, London]] {{sports-venue-stub}}

[[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|VIC]] 3000
[[Australia]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = October 1954 | built = | opened = {{Start date|1956|11|22|df=yes}} | renovated = 1983, 2003, 2013 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Melbourne & Olympic Parks Trust | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = [[Australian pound|£]]350,000
[[Australian dollar|$]]10.5 million (1983 renovation)
$20 million (2003 renovation) | architect = [[Kevin Borland]], [[Peter McIntyre (architect)|Peter McIntyre]] and [[John and Phyllis Murphy]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = Bill Irwin | services engineer = | general_contractor = McDougall & Ireland | main_contractors = | capacity = 7,200 (1983-98)

[[Collingwood Football Club]] (Training facility) (2003-present)
[[Victorian Institute of Sport]] (Training facility) (2003-present) | embedded = | website = {{URL|https://www.mopt.com.au/about/history/holden-centre/|Venue Website}} | publictransit = }} The '''Holden Centre''' (originally known as the '''Swimming and Diving Stadium''' and formerly known as the '''Olympic Swimming Stadium''', '''Melbourne Sports and Entertainment Centre''', '''Holden Centre''', and unofficially '''The Glass House''') is a sports administration and training facility located in the [[Melbourne Sports and Entertainment Precinct]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]]. The facility opened in 1956 as an aquatic centre for the [[1956 Summer Olympics|1956 Olympic Games]]. In 1983, the Olympic-sized pool was replaced with a parquetry floor and the facility became Melbourne's home to numerous basketball events until 1998, most notably as the home venue for several [[National Basketball League (Australasia)|National Basketball League]] teams including the [[North Melbourne Giants]] and [[Melbourne Tigers]]. The venue served as Melbourne's primary indoor concert arena from 1984 to 1988, until the completion of the [[Rod Laver Arena]]. ==History== ===1956 Olympic Games=== Known originally as the '''Swimming and Diving Stadium''', it was built as an indoor aquatic centre for [[Diving (sport)|diving]], [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[Water polo at the 1956 Summer Olympics|water polo]], and the swimming part of the [[Modern pentathlon at the 1956 Summer Olympics|modern pentathlon]] events for the [[1956 Summer Olympics]].{{cite web |url=http://vhd.heritage.vic.gov.au/#detail_places;2038|title= Victorian Heritage Database - OLYMPIC SWIMMING STADIUM|accessdate=2007-09-27|work= Heritage Council of Victoria}}{{Cite report |editor=Doyle, Edward A|date=1958 |title=The Official Report of the Organizing Committee for the Games of the XVI Olympiad, Melbourne 1956 |url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1956/OR1956.pdf |publisher=Organizing Committee of the XVI Olympiad |pages=41–42 |asin=B00CHQ4LLO |accessdate=5 November 2013 |quote= }} It was the first fully indoor Olympic swimming venue in an [[Olympic Games]] and is the only major [[stadium]] structure from the 1956 Olympic Games with the [[facade]] intact. It is listed on the [[Victorian Heritage Register]].{{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/87357/default.aspx |title=Magpies seek new naming rights partner for HQ |author= |date= |website=[[Australian Football League]] |publisher= |accessdate=5 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001082802/http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/87357/default.aspx |archivedate=October 1, 2012 }} The design of this building was the winner of one of three international competitions held in 1952 to provide stadia for the 1956 Olympic Games. Architects [[Kevin Borland]], [[Peter McIntyre (architect)|Peter McIntyre]], [[John and Phyllis Murphy]] and their engineer Bill Irwin won the only one of these competitions to be consummated. Construction by McDougall & Ireland, one of Melbourne's then-largest construction companies, began in October 1954 and was completed in 1956, just prior to the commencement of the Melbourne Olympic Games. ===Basketball=== After redevelopment in the 1980s, the venue became the '''Melbourne Sports and Entertainment Centre'''. It hosted home games for the [[National Basketball League (Australia)|National Basketball League]]'s [[North Melbourne Giants]], as well as the [[Melbourne Tigers]], [[South East Melbourne Magic|Eastside Spectres]] and [[Southern Melbourne Saints|Westside Melbourne Saints]], as well as hosting international games between the [[Australian boomers|Australian Boomers]] and various visiting international teams including the [[Soviet Union national basketball team|Soviet Union]] who played there in 1987.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ZKPTSdoVTc 1987 Australian Boomers vs USSR basketball] The Giants would remain at The Glass House until their final season in [[1998 NBL season|1998]]. The Tigers would move to the 15,400 capacity (for basketball) [[Rod Laver Arena|National Tennis Centre]] at [[Melbourne Park|Flinders Park]] in [[1992 NBL season|1992]], while the Spectres and Saints merged in [[1991 NBL season|1991]] to become the [[South East Melbourne Magic]]. The Magic would also move to Melbourne Park in 1992 leaving the Giants as the only NBL tenants at the venue. From 1984 until 1986, The Glass house with its 7,200 capacity was the largest venue used in the NBL. Its position was taken when the [[Brisbane Bullets]] moved into the 13,500 seat [[Brisbane Entertainment Centre]] in mid-1986. By the time of the venue's last NBL game on Friday 5 June 1998 which saw the Giants defeat the [[Perth Wildcats]] 109–103, The Glass House was still the 4th largest venue in use, though having opened in 1956 it was also the oldest. The North Melbourne Giants won the NBL Championship at The Glass House in [[1989 NBL season|1989]] when they defeated the [[Canberra Cannons]] 2-0 in the Grand Final series, reversing the result of the [[1988 NBL Finals|1988]] [[NBL Grand Final]] when they had lost to the Cannons.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HK1cdpB3fa4 1988 NBL Grand Final][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b366xrMS1T0 1989 NBL Grand Final] They won their second and last title in [[1994 NBL season|1994]] when they defeated the [[Adelaide 36ers]], again 2-0 in the best of three series.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jl8TbEO0oiY 1994 NBL Finals] The Glass House also hosted the [[NBL (Australia) All-Star Game|NBL All-Star Game]] in 1988, 1989 and 1991. ===Concert venue=== The Glass House, which after its redevelopment into a Sports and Entertainment Centre had a capacity of 7,200 people, was also used as Melbourne's main indoor concert venue until the opening of the 16,000 capacity National Tennis Centre in 1988. ==Sponsorship and naming rights arrangements== The luxury vehicle manufacturer [[Lexus]] bought the [[naming rights]] to the venue in 2004; as the '''Lexus Centre''', it no longer served as a public stadium, instead being used by the [[Victorian Institute of Sport]] and the [[Collingwood Football Club]] as a sports administration and training facility. The Lexus Centre was listed as part of the [[Melbourne Sports and Entertainment Precinct]]. On 21 November 2009, Collingwood Football Club announced publicly on the official AFL website that Lexus would no longer continue to maintain the rights of naming the centre. Lexus announced in a statement that "the branding exercise had achieved its marketing objectives and was no longer a priority in its marketing strategy", hence ending a six-year naming rights deal between Lexus and Collingwood.{{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/87357/default.aspx |title=Magpies seek new naming rights partner for HQ |author= |date= |website=[[Australian Football League]] |publisher= |accessdate=5 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001082802/http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/87357/default.aspx |archivedate=October 1, 2012 }} In March, 2010, Collingwood announced that [[Westpac]] bank was the new naming rights sponsor of the centre.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.crikey.com.au/sports/2010/03/23/collingwood-announce-new-westpac-centre-sponsorship-westpac-announce-interest-rate-rise-coincidence/ |title=Collingwood announce new "Westpac Centre" sponsorship, Westpac announce interest rate rise. Coincidence? |last1=Josey |first1=Leigh |last2= |first2= |date=23 March 2010 |website=[[Crikey]] |publisher=Private Media Partners |accessdate=5 November 2013}} On 19 August 2015, [[Holden]] signed a multimillion-dollar three-year deal to become a Premier Partner of Collingwood and holder of the naming rights to the club’s headquarters at Olympic Park, now known as the 'Holden Centre'.{{cite web|url=http://www.collingwoodfc.com.au/news/2015-08-19/introducing-the-holden-centre|title=Introducing the Holden Centre|first=Stephen|last=Rielly|publisher=[[BigPond]]|work=[[Collingwood Football Club|collingwoodfc.com.au]]|date=19 August 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons-inline}} *[http://www.venues.com.au/venue.php?id=606 Westpac Centre, Venues.com.au] *[http://www.vis.org.au/ Victorian Institute of Sport] *[http://www.collingwoodfc.com.au/ Collingwood Football Club] *{{austadiums|123}} {{coord|37|49|27|S|144|58|47|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Melbourne United}} {{1956 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues diving}} {{Olympic venues modern pentathlon}} {{Olympic venues swimming}} {{Olympic venues water polo}} {{NBL Arenas|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1956]] [[Category:Venues of the 1956 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Sports venues in Melbourne]] [[Category:Defunct National Basketball League (Australia) venues]] [[Category:Netball venues in Australia]] [[Category:Heritage listed buildings in Melbourne]] [[Category:Swimming venues in Australia]] [[Category:Collingwood Football Club]] [[Category:Lexus]] [[Category:Olympic diving venues]] [[Category:Olympic modern pentathlon venues]] [[Category:Olympic swimming venues]] [[Category:Olympic water polo venues]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Australia]] [[Category:North Melbourne Giants]] [[Category:Melbourne United]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Rickwood Field | logo_image = | image = Rickwood Field.jpg | caption = | location = 1137 2nd Avenue West, [[Birmingham, Alabama]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = Spring 1910 | cost = $75,000 | opened = August 18, 1910 | owner = City of Birmingham | operator = | surface = Grass | architect = | tenants = [[Birmingham Barons]] (Southern Association) – 1910–1961
[[Birmingham Barons]] (Southern League) – 1964–1965, 1981–1987, part-time 1988–present
[[Birmingham A's]] (Southern League) – 1967–1975
[[Birmingham Black Barons]] (Negro Southern League) – 1920–1924, 1926, 1931–1936, 1938–1939
[[Birmingham Black Barons]] (Negro National League) – 1925–1926, 1927–1930, 1937, 1940–1948
[[Birmingham Black Barons]] (Negro American League) – 1949–1960
[[Philadelphia Phillies]] (Major League Baseball Spring Training) - 1911, 1920
[[Pittsburgh Pirates]] (Major League Baseball Spring Training) - 1919 | seating_capacity = 10,800 | record_attendance = | dimensions = Left field: {{convert|321|ft|m}}
Left center: {{convert|399|ft|m}}
Center field: {{convert|393|ft|m}}
Right center: {{convert|392|ft|m}}
Right field: {{convert|332|ft|m}} {{Infobox NRHP|embed=yes | name = Rickwood Field | nrhp_type = | image = | caption = | location= | coordinates = {{coord|33|30|8|N|86|51|21|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = | built = 1910 | architecture = | added = February 1, 1993 | area = {{convert|12.7|acre}} | governing_body = | refnum = 92001826{{NRISref|2009a}} | designated_other1 = ARLH | designated_other1_date = December 19, 1991 }} }} '''Rickwood Field''', located in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], is the oldest professional [[baseball]] park in the United States. It was built for the [[Birmingham Barons]] in 1910 by industrialist and team-owner [[Rick Woodward]] and has served as the home park for the Birmingham Barons and the [[Birmingham Black Barons]] of the [[Negro League baseball|Negro Leagues]]. Though the Barons moved their home games to the Hoover Met in the suburbs, and most recently to [[Regions Field]] in Birmingham, Rickwood Field has been preserved and is undergoing gradual restoration as a "working [[museum]]" where baseball's history can be experienced. The Barons also play one regular season game a year at Rickwood Field. Rickwood Field is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. ==History== The Birmingham Coal Barons baseball team began playing professionally in 1887, with their home games at an informal park called "Slag Pile Field" in West End. In 1901 they joined the [[Southern Association]]. Allen Harvey "Rick" Woodward, chairman of Woodward Iron Company and grandson of pioneer Birmingham industrialist Stimpson Harvey Woodward, purchased a majority share of the Birmingham Coal Barons baseball team from J. William McQueen in 1909 while he was still in his 20s. Immediately he began planning a grand showplace for his new team. He contacted [[Connie Mack]] for advice on the details, including the field dimensions. He settled on [[Shibe Park]] in [[Philadelphia]] (which was controlled by Mack's team and later renamed Connie Mack Stadium) and [[Forbes Field]] in [[Pittsburgh]] as the models for the new park. He purchased land in the West End neighborhood of Birmingham from the Alabama Central Railroad. The $75,000 structure was designed by Southeastern Engineering Company of Birmingham (a short-lived subsidiary of [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]]'s General Fireproofing Company) and completed during the summer of 1910. The 12.7 [[acre]] (51,000 m²) park was flanked along the basepaths by concrete and steel stands. A tile-roofed cupola on the roof behind home plate provided space for the announcer and the press. Woodward named the field after himself, using his nickname and the first part of his last name. It was the first concrete-and-steel stadium in the minors. Woodward invited Alabama Governor [[Braxton Bragg Comer]], Birmingham Mayor Culpepper Exum, civic leader, [[George B. Ward]] and Victor H. Hanson, publisher of ''[[The Birmingham News]]'', for opening day on August 18, 1910. The day was celebrated by businesses closing all over town to allow fans to fill the park for the first pitch at 3:30 P.M. Over 10,000 people attended that first game in which the Barons defeated the visiting Montgomery Climbers 3-2. Throughout the first half of the 20th century Rickwood Field hosted sellout crowds for both the Barons and the Black Barons, who played on alternate weekends. In 1912 a spring [[tornado]] tore through the field, pulling up the outfield fence. Two years later Woodward felt the need to have electric fans installed in the grandstands for the comfort of the crowd. The [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] also made Rickwood Field their [[spring training]] home in [[1919 in baseball|1919]]. Rickwood Field also hosted [[college football]] games. From 1912 to 1927 the [[Alabama Crimson Tide]] played its Birmingham home dates in Rickwood. In 1921 the outfield fence was damaged in a tornado and quickly rebuilt. In 1924–1927 the infield bleachers were covered with a steel-framed roof designed by Denham, VanKeuren & Denham, Architects of Birmingham. Shortly after, In 1928 a new [[Mission Revival Style architecture|Mission style]] entry structure with offices was built to the designs of Paul Wright & Co., Engineers of Birmingham. A new concrete outfield wall replaced the original fence. In 1931 in the first game of the Dixie Series championship, Birmingham's 43-year-old [[Ray Caldwell]] outpitched 22-year-old [[Dizzy Dean]], who had guaranteed a win. The Barons won the series 4 games to 3. In 1936 four monumental steel-frame light towers designed and fabricated by the Truscon Steel Company of [[Youngstown, Ohio]] were erected, allowing for night games. In 1938, Woodward sold the park to Ed Norton, a local businessman. In 1940 Norton sold it to the Cincinnati Reds. At that time new outfield fences were built inside the original walls to reduce the field dimensions. G. J. Jebeles of Birmingham purchased the park in 1944. A ladies' rest room was added and the outfield fence reduced again in 1948. In 1949 ownership changed hands again, going to a partnership of Al DeMent, Al Belcher, and Rufus Lackey. They added a small restaurant in the entrance building in 1950 and installed additional box seats, necessitating the relocations of the dugouts farther down the baselines. In 1958 Belcher gained a majority share and control of the park. In 1964 General Manager Glynn West purchased 1000 wooden seats from New York City's [[Polo Grounds]] and installed them at the park. Belcher sold Rickwood Field in 1966 to the City of Birmingham, but retained a lease for the remainder of that year. In 1966 the lease was transferred to [[Charles O. Finley|Charlie Finley]], who brought the [[Oakland Athletics|Kansas City Athletics']] AA farm team to Birmingham for the 1967 season. That year is remembered for the day that 14,000 disappointed fans were sent home early when the [[Atlanta Braves]] vs. Southern League All-Stars exhibition game was called "on account of tornado." During this period, following a trend which swept [[minor league baseball]] (and which has since been largely reversed), the team took the name of the parent [[Major League Baseball|major league]] club and was known as the "Birmingham A's". Between 1979 and 1980 the wooden seats were replaced with plastic seats in the box areas and metal bleachers under the grandstands.{{cite web|last=Mercer|first=Chloe S.|author2=Melanie A. Betz|title=Rickwood Field |url={{NRHP url|id=92001826}}|work=National Register of Historic Places Registration Form|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=March 17, 2014|date=August 19, 1992|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O9gfxXrB |archivedate=March 17, 2014|deadurl=no}} ''See also:'' {{cite web|title=Accompanying photos|url={{NRHP url|id=92001826|photos=y}}|accessdate=March 17, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O9ggh0zK |archivedate=March 17, 2014|deadurl=no}} In 1981 Art Clarkson brought minor league baseball back to Rickwood with the Detroit Tigers AA club, which resumed the Barons name. He had a new electronic scoreboard installed at the park. In 1986, the Barons became the Chicago White Sox AA club, an affiliation that continues today. In 1987 the Barons moved to a new facility, [[Hoover Metropolitan Stadium]], in the [[suburb]] of [[Hoover, Alabama|Hoover]]. They returned to Birmingham in 2013 with the opening of [[Regions Field]], just south of downtown Birmingham. ==Current status== Since 1992 the ballpark has been under the care of the [http://www.rickwood.com Friends of Rickwood] who are restoring the facility to its former glory. They also host frequent amateur, police and semi-pro games and open the gates to visitors who can walk in and explore the grandstands or run the bases. Since 1996, Rickwood Field has hosted the Barons for a throwback game in which both teams wear period uniforms. Each game honors a different era in Birmingham baseball history. Ballpark enthusiasts from across North America migrate to Rickwood to attend this AA regulation game, named the "Rickwood Classic", every season. Many consider this game the best opportunity to experience a regulation ballgame in an historic ballpark that remains true to its original and traditional appearance. Those involved – the Barons franchise, Friends of Rickwood, and fans – fully believe that this experience in the sacred baseball cathedral is among the most underrated baseball events. Scenes from the movies ''[[Cobb (film)|Cobb]]'' (1994) and ''Soul of the Game'' (1995) were filmed at Rickwood. Those productions contributed to the recreation of the scoreboard and press-box and the addition of 1940s period style advertisements on the outfield fence. Some of these retro-style ads have been sponsored by real Birmingham businesses, including a section sponsored by the descendants of Rick Woodward that advertises long-gone Woodward Iron Co. The outfield signs were designed by Ted Haigh, a Los Angeles-based graphic designer and executed by Skidmore Sign Company of Birmingham. In May 2012, scenes from the [[film|movie]] ''[[42 (film)|42]]'' were also filmed at Rickwood Field. As of 2005, the Friends of Rickwood have spent around $2 million refurbishing the grandstands, press-box, locker rooms, roof and main entrance to the park. Future plans include establishing a Museum of Southern Baseball. Since 2011 Play at the Plate Baseball has held an annual 3 day adult baseball tournament with 4 teams from various regions of the country participating. The event is usually held in June. [[ESPN Classic]] broadcast a re-enactment of a [[Negro Leagues|Negro League]] game played at Rickwood on February 26, 2006. It featured teams wearing the uniforms of the fictitious "Bristol Barnstormers" (named for ESPN's hometown of [[Bristol, Connecticut]]) and the [[Birmingham Black Barons]]. ==Gallery== Image:Rickwood entrance.png|Rickwood Field facade Image:Rickwood site plan.png|Plan of the field Image:Post-game fun.jpg|Field Image:Birmingham Black Baron's Left Fielder.jpg|Scoreboard Image:Rickwood Championships.jpg|Rickwood Championships ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite book | author=Benson, Michael | title=Ballparks of North America: A Comprehensive Historical Reference to Grounds, Yards, and Stadiums, 1845-Present | publisher=McFarlands | year=1989 | id=ISBN}} *Wainwright, Paige. "Rickwood Field: Grand Old Lady of Baseball." ''Alabama Heritage'', Fall 1995. *{{cite book | author=Whitt, Timothy | title=Bases Loaded with History: The Story of Rickwood Field: America's Oldest Baseball Park | location=Birmingham, Alabama | publisher=R. Boozer Press | year=1995 | isbn=0-9636128-1-6}} *[[United States Geological Survey]] (2006). {{Gnis3|125622}}. Retrieved 1 February 2006. ==External links== {{Commons category|Rickwood Field}} * [http://www.rickwood.com Rickwood Field (Friends of Rickwood) website] * [http://www.baseballpilgrimages.com/rickwood.html Rickwood Field at Baseball Pilgrimages.com] * {{HABS |survey=AL-897 |id=al0965 |title=Rickwood Field, 1137 Second Avenue West, Birmingham, Jefferson County, AL |photos=28 |color= |dwgs=22 |data=58 |cap=2}} * [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/pauls2004parks/Stadiums/Birmingham/Rickwood.htm&date=2009-10-26+00:19:21 Rickwood Field Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{Alabama Crimson Tide football navbox}} {{Philadelphia Phillies}} {{Pittsburgh Pirates}} {{Birmingham Landmarks}} [[Category:Baseball museums and halls of fame]] [[Category:Defunct college football venues]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Negro league baseball venues]] [[Category:Alabama Crimson Tide football venues]] [[Category:Pittsburgh Pirates spring training venues]] [[Category:Philadelphia Phillies spring training venues]] [[Category:International Sports Heritage Association]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Birmingham, Alabama]] [[Category:Properties on the Alabama Register of Landmarks and Heritage]] [[Category:Museums in Birmingham, Alabama]] [[Category:Sports venues in Birmingham, Alabama]] [[Category:Negro league baseball venues still standing]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Alabama]] [[Category:Landmarks in Alabama]] [[Category:Sports museums in Alabama]] [[Category:Historic American Buildings Survey in Alabama]] [[Category:1910 establishments in Alabama]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1910]]
